Title: Alien Revolt
URL: No website for game currently exists
Description: Multi-player game, which requires access to a GPRS network and a cell phone. Alien Revolt tells the story of a group of alien creatures who try to take over the Earth. Players can decide to join the human forces or the alien army, and choose between three classes of characters: Magus, Hacker, or Warrior, each of which has different attributes and abilities. Gameplay involves dueling opponents (who are within the 3km of proximity); however, the closer the opponent, the more likely that "shots fired" will be accurate. The purpose of gameplay is to kill opponents to gain points and to steal their possessions.
Articles: https://www.blasttheory.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Day-of-the-Figurines-A-Slow-Narrative-Driven-Game-for-Mobile-Phones-Using-Text-Messaging-2007.pdf (Flintham, M., Smith, K., Benford, S., Capra, M., Green, J., Greenhalgh, C., Wright, M., & Tandavanitj, N. Day of the Figurines : A Slow Narrative-Driven Game for Mobile Phones Using Text Messaging), https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4468731/ (A. de Souza e Silva, "Alien Revolt (2005-2007): A Case Study of the First Location-Based Mobile Game in Brazil," in IEEE Technology and Society Magazine, vol. 27, no. 1, pp. 18-28, Spring 2008, doi: 10.1109/MTS.2008.918036)

Title: Big Urban Game
Description: Big Urban Game (B.U.G.) consisted of a 5-day event occurring across the streets of Minneapolis and St. Paul in 2003 (Lantz, 2006); 200 square miles becomes the canvas for a spectacle that transforms the everyday into a site of unfamiliarity and the sublime. Three teams raced conspicuous 25-foot-tall red, yellow, and blue inflatable game pieces through the cities orchestrated by public decisions registered on the B.U.G. Web site. The aim of B.U.G. is for teams to visit all the sites in the quickest time. It is up to the players to decide how they will move from site to site and, therefore, achieve the game’s goal.
Articles: https://gothamist.com/miscellaneous/bug-big-urban-game (Report, Gothamist (2003)), https://journals-sagepub-com.prox.lib.ncsu.edu/doi/abs/10.1177/1046878109333723#articleCitationDownloadContainer (de Souza e Silva, Adriana, & Hjorth, L. Title: Botfighters
URL: No website for game currently exists
Description: Multiplayer game which "uses GSM Network Cell identification" to find nearby players. The purpose of the game is to fight other "bots" and to gain points by killing other bots, which gives players points and allows them to purchase defensive protections, such as armors and shields. The game is "always-on," which means that a player can be attacked at any time and in any place where other players convene. Attack and counter-attacks were carried out by SMS commands initially, but later the game upgraded to a Java-based application.
Articles: http://news.cision.com/its-alive-mobile-games/r/it-s-alive-and-dna-launch-finland-s-first-location-based-mobile-game,c51699 (Review, Cision News (2001)), http://www.digra.org/wp-content/uploads/digital-library/05164.14477.pdf (Sotamaa, O. (2002). All The World's A Botfighter Stage: Notes on Location-based Multi-User Gaming. CGDC Conf.), https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2002/aug/15/electronicgoods.games (Article, The Guardian (2002))

Title: Can You See Me Now?
Developers: Blast Theory, Mixed Reality Lab (University of Nottingham)
URL: https://www.blasttheory.co.uk/projects/can-you-see-me-now/ (Can you see me now? | Blast Theory)
Description: Multiplayer game, in which players (called "runners) navigate a city with the goal of catching a remote, online player. The position of the runner is tracked by satellite. The online players must simultaneously navigate a digital reproduction of the city using the arrow keys of their computer's keyboard and, in doing so, avoid being caught by the runners who are navigating the actual physical city.

Title: CitiTag
Developers: HP Labs, Open University’s Knowledge Media Institute (KMi)
URL: No website for game currently exists
Description: A classic game of "Tag, you're it" through a ipaq pocket PC interface, in which players use GPS to navigate the city an search for other participating players. Upon finding an opposing player, a player can "tag" them-- in which case, they must find a friend to free them before they can find other players to tag.
Articles: http://kmi.open.ac.uk/publications/papers/kmi_tr_147.pdf (Quick, K., Vogiazou, Y. (2004), http://kmi.open.ac.uk/publications/papers/kmi_tr_139.pdf (Y. Vogiazou et al. You got tagged!: The city as a playground. In Proc. of 2AD’04, 2004)

Title: CityHunters
Description: A location-based mobile game, which makes use of a GPS (connected via Bluetooth) and acceleromoter (attached to the shell of a Nokia phone and connected via Bluetooth) to track the movements and motions of players as they move through a city. Data from the GPS/accelerometer is communicated via GPRS network and appears on a digital map through the Nokia phone. The purpose of gameplay is to "shoot" other players, who have accepted a game play challenge. The players use the GPS information to determine the location of other players; they use their accelerometer to tilt their phone and angle shots toward opponents. In addition to firing shots at other players, players can also virtually destroy the physical structures of the city.

Title: ConQwest
Description: ConQwest is a team-based treasure hunt game, which uses implied positioning from semacode tags; it is sponsored by Qwest Wireless in the USA to promote its camera phones. As the players’ position is implied, the game area must be set-up prior to the game by placing semacode stickers at defined locations around the selected urban landscape. Each sticker is given a relative value, the players collect the stickers by taking pictures with their phone cameras. The first team to collect $5000 worth of semacodes wins. The set-up requirement is undoubtedly a limitation, although this is largely compensated for by the finer degree of localization and physical interaction within that space.
Articles: https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/1111293.1111302 (Rashid, O., Mullins, I., Coulton, P., & Edwards, R. (2006). Extending cyberspace: Location based games using cellular phones. (2009). Playful urban spaces: A historical approach to mobile games. Simulation & Gaming, 40(5), 602-625. doi:10.1177/1046878109333723)

Title: Day Of The Figurines
Developers: Blast Theory, Mixed Reality Lab (University of Nottingham)
Description:
Day of the Figurines (DoF) is a text messaging pervasive
game for mobile phones that is designed to be slow and
interwoven with the patterns of players’ daily lives over a
month of play. It is a massively multiplayer game, set in a fictional town that is littered, dark and underpinned with steady decay. To begin the game, players are invited to create their own figurine: to name it, answer questions about its past and how it is represented to other players. All interaction is via mobile phones.

Title: Decay Watch
URL: No active website for game currently exists
Description: Decay Watch is another treasure hunt style game, using Cell-ID or GPS, where players eliminate decay in cities by searching out and location-tagging decay, identified as graffiti, littered beaches, run-down buildings, etc. The most interesting aspect of the game is that it features mobile blogging and mobile chat between players; it was released in partnership with an existing online gaming community.

Title: Epidemic Menace
Description: In Epidemic Menace, players become medical experts to save mankind threatened by a mutated virus. A villain scientist, craving power, creates a lethal mutation and contaminates a university campus with it. From there the virus spreads and infects all humans. Teams of experts – the players – are assigned the task of defeating this threat. They have three hours in which to destroy the virus before it escapes the campus; the teams must also uncover where the mutant virus came from and how it came to be. Each team has a room equipped with stationary devices that allow players to observe and analyze the virus and to communicate with other team members. In addition to the stationary devices in the game room, each team receives a set of devices that can be used outdoors to capture and destroy the virus.

Title: Frequency 1550
Description: Frequency 1550 was a mobile city game that used GPS and UMTS technology to let pupils of the secondary schools actively learn about history instead of passively absorb knowledge. The aim of Frequency 1550 was to bring the Middle Ages alive for pupils, within their history lessons.
Articles: https://waag.org/en/project/frequency-1550 (Review, The Waag Society (2007)), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chb.2010.12.013 (Admiraal, W., Huizenga, J., Akkerman, S., & Dam, G. t. (2011). The concept of flow in collaborative game-based learning. Computers in Human Behavior, 27(3), 1185-1194. doi:10.1016/j.chb.2010.12.013)

Title: GPS Mission
Description: GPS mission is a mobile-app based game that makes use of the player's phone's GPS to track their location as they move about a city. To play, players must accept a challenge, which directs them to go to a particular location. At this particular location, they may collect virtual gold. Alternatively, they may be asked to interact with the place in a particular way; for instance, some users are asked to solve riddles. Additionally, the app allows users to drop "waymarks" to show where they have been; they can also upload photos to show where they have been.
Articles: https://appscout.pcmag.com/mobile-apps/274009-orbster-gps-mission-for-the-iphone (Report, PCMag (2008)), https://www.intomobile.com/2009/01/15/orbsters-gps-mission-iphone-game-makes-the-world-your-oyster/ (Review, Intomobile (2009)), https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-75256-3_2 (Spallazzo D., Mariani I. (2018) LBMG in a Nutshell. In: Location-Based Mobile Games. SpringerBriefs in Applied Sciences and Technology. Springer, Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-75256-3_2)

Title: GPS::Tron
Description: GPS::Tron is a multiplayer game for java-enabled mobile phones that are based on a variation on the arcade classic. Tron players move in real space; and GPS is used to track and locate users. GPS::Tron utilizes a cell phone that is connected—via Bluetooth—to an external GPS receiver. This racing game sets two players side-by-side on a digital grid, each driving a different colored vehicle. The players begin driving forward, leaving in their path a digital trail of their vehicle’s color. This trail forms a wall that neither player can cross again, thus making the goal of the game to trap the other player within the digital walls created by the vehicles. Players can pick bonus materials that allow them to get shields and breakthrough a trail left by opponents.The vehicles, however, do not necessarily need to be physically next to each other for the game to work. One player can begin the game on the streets of Los Angeles while the opponent begins the game on the streets of Sydney. Their locations are mapped onto the digital representation of their vehicles on the GPS interface, allowing players from around the globe to compete with each other.
Articles: https://ojs.library.queensu.ca/index.php/surveillance-and-society/article/view/misuse/misuses (Farman, J. (2014). Creative misuse as resistance: Surveillance, mobile technologies, and locative games. Surveillance & Society, 12(3), 377-388. doi:10.24908/ss.v12i3.4981), https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/1111293.1111302 (Rashid, O., Mullins, I., Coulton, P., & Edwards, R. (2006). Extending cyberspace: Location based games using cellular phones. Title: Geko Smak
Description: A rendition of the arcade/fair game "whack-a-mole" in which players must navigate, in the physical world, to the location of a virtual "gecko" in order to "smack" it (which gives the user points). The game relies on the Garmin Geko 201 device, which has this game and three others pre-loaded onto the device).
Articles: https://www.forbes.com/2003/03/11/cx_ah_0311tentech.html#19c831402b27 (Article, Forbes (2003)), https://www.pocketgpsworld.com/garmingeko.php (Review, PocketGPSWorld (2003))

Title: Geocaching
Description: Geocaching is an outdoor activity, which involves players finding clues and GPS coordinates online and, then, seeking out a "cache" based on the clues and coordinates. The object of Geocaching is to decode the clues and coordinates to find the cache. Upon finding the cache, players typically sign their name to a log and, in some cases, leave objects behind (known as treasures or swag) which can be traded with other players who find the cache. Additionally, some caches contain "trackables," which are objects that contain unique identifiers. Players can collect trackables and move them to another cache in a different location; players who find trackables use the unique identifier to update their location, so that others can track their movement over time.
Articles: http://homenewshere.com/tewksbury_town_crier/news/article_451acdea-4177-11e7-b5d7-8398b83c1a45.html (Article, Tewksbury Town Crier (2017)), https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00779-011-0497-7 (Neustaedter, C., Tang, A. & Judge, T.K. Creating scalable location-based games: lessons from Geocaching. Pers Ubiquit Comput 17, 335–349 (2013). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00779-011-0497-7), https://www.wsj.com/articles/want-a-modern-day-treasure-hunt-try-geocaching-1526566932 (Article, The Wall Street Journal (2018))

Title: Geodashing
URL: http://geodashing.gpsgames.org/ (Geodashing - Getting There is All the Fun)
Description: Geodashing involves players, across the world, racing to see who can visit the most number of dash points before a specific deadline. Dash points are specific locations that are randomly selected by computer algorithm and can be located anywhere. The objective of the game is for players to gain points for each place visited. Although there is no "winner," competition exists by seeing who can accumulate the most points. Unlike a similar game, Geocaching, there is no logbook, cache, or swag at a particular location. Players can play individual or in teams of people up to five.
Articles: https://moreexploringoffthebeatenpath.com/2012/04/30/give-geodashing-a-try/ (Review, More Exploring Off the Beaten Path (2012)), http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.530.8727&rep=rep1&type=pdf (Li, M., O'Grady, M., & O'Hare, G.M. (2008). Geo-Gaming: The Mobile Monopoly Experience. WEBIST)

Title: Go Game Classic
Description: The Go Game is an urban adventure game played on mobile phones. Teams of 4-8 people are equipped with a map, digital camera, and phone, on which they receive 'missions' to complete throughout the game. These messages ask players to solve a riddle, visit a local landmark, create a photo or video masterpiece, or interact with a Go Game secret agent. After the game, teams get together at a pub and watch the photos and videos on a big screen. They vote via mobile phone on which team is the funniest, the most daring, or who took off the most clothes – it's up to the audience! The half-day events are a natural fit for corporate team building, marketing new products, innovative trainings and pure fun.
Articles: https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2009/may/13/the-go-game-london-pervasive-gaming (Article, The Guardian (2009)), https://thenextweb.com/insider/2011/08/10/meet-the-go-game-the-godfathers-of-geo/ (Article, The Next Web (2011)), https://www.avantgame.com/MCGONIGAL%20A%20Real%20Little%20Game%20DiGRA%202003.pdf (McGonigal J (2003) A real little game: the pinocchio effect in pervasive play. In: Marinka C, Joost R (eds) Level up conference proceedings: proceedings of the 2003 digital games research association conference. CD ROM. University of Utrecht, Utrecht), https://gigaom.com/2011/07/11/the-go-game-app-team-building-though-mobile-games/ (Review, GigaOm (2011))

Title: I like Frank
Developers: Blast Theory, Mixed Reality Lab (University of Nottingham)
Description: Online players use a virtual map to navigate the city of Adelaide to find and open photos in specific locations. One of the potential photos that they can open offers the location of a hidden object. Once the hidden object is uncovered, the online player must ask a player in the physical world to navigate to that hidden object. Once a player in the physical world agrees to go find the hidden object, the physical world player begins receiving messages about a character "Frank" and his journey with the game's creator, which mirrors the journey that the physical world player is currently on. Upon finding the hidden object (a postcard with a question), the physical world player then directs the question that is on the postcard to the online player.
Articles: http://eleven.fibreculturejournal.org/fcj-073-technology-transfer-present-and-futures-in-the-electronic-arts/ (Degger, B. (2008). Technology transfer present and futures in the electronic arts. Fibreculture Journal, (11)), https://www.blasttheory.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/Review_ILF_Visual-Arts-Culture-Broadsheet_Volume33-No1-02-03-2004.pdf (Review, Contemporary Visual Arts + Culture Broadsheet (2004)), https://www.blasttheory.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/Review_ILF_British-Council-Australia_-2003.pdf (Review, British Council Australia (2003))

Title: Memory Race
URL: no website for the game, only for the device: https://buy.garmin.com/en-US/US/p/220#specs (Geko 201)
Description: A classic game of "matching pairs by memory" through a GPS interface. The GPS interface is divided into tiles. To "flip" a tile and find matching tiles, the player must navigate in space to the position of the tile. Once a tile is flipped, the player then moves through space to flip another tile with the hope that both flipped tiles match one another. The game continues until the player has successfully matched all tiles, which constitutes a win.
Articles: https://www.pocketgpsworld.com/garmingeko.php (Review, PocketGPSWorld (2003))

Title: Mogi
URL: No website for game currently exists
Description: MOGI is a Japanese hybrid reality game. MOGI’s goal is to collect location-based virtual objects and creatures around the city of Tokyo with the cell phone. Players may also see other nearby players on the radar of their cell phone screen and exchange virtual objects. Online players may also guide street players to find specific items for their collections.
Articles: http://www.links.net/share/write/thefeature/Mogi__Second_Generation_Location-Based_Gaming.html (Article, TheFeature (2004)), https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/fe6c/42ffbb2d7cbade82189171ae009ed2ff2206.pdf (Chan, D. (2008). Convergence, Connectivity, and the Case of Japanese Mobile Gaming. Games and Culture, 3, 13 - 25), https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10630730802677905?journalCode=cjut20 (Licoppe, C., & Inada, Y. (2008). Geolocalized technologies, location-aware communities, and personal territories: The mogi case. The Journal of Urban Technology, 15(3), 5-24. doi:10.1080/10630730802677905)

Title: NavBall
Description: NavBall is a multiplayer game that used GPS phones to create an action-packed 45-minute match across the city of Amsterdam. It features 2 teams of 11 players each that will attempt to score as many goals. The “ball” and “goal” are placed on a map of Amsterdam and the players have to get into formation to kick the “ball” at the right angle and speed to make a goal. The players have to move around the city with their GPS enabled phones in order to achieve this.
Articles: https://geosmart.wordpress.com/2008/12/04/location-innovation-and-navball/ (Blog, GeoSmart (2008)), https://www.mediamatic.net/en/page/42404/navball-nl (Report, Mediamatic (2008))

Title: Nibbons
URL: no website for the game, only for the device: https://buy.garmin.com/en-US/US/p/220#specs (Geko 201)
Description: The game of "Snake" on a GPS interface which requires a player to physical navigate a space toward particular numbers; however, players cannot move to a place they have recently been and, thus, step on their "tail" which constitutes losing the game.
Articles: https://www.pocketgpsworld.com/garmingeko.php (Review, PocketGPSWorld (2003))

Title: Noderunner
Developers: Yury Gitman, Carlos J. Gomez de Llarena
Description: In Noderunner, the cityscape of Manhattan is reterritorialized into hot and cold spots—determined by access to the Internet. The aim of the game, in which two teams are pitted against each other, is to access and document (via camera phones) as many of the wireless Internet nodes as possible while attempting to get from Bryant Park in midtown to Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan. Teams are given a Wi-Fi-enabled laptop, a digital camera, taxi fare, and 2 hours. Points are obtained by taking camera phone pictures of themselves in the exact spot at which they connected to the wireless Internet; they are also awarded points for using scanning software to find the nodes on their journey.

Title: PAC-LAN
Description: A location-based version of Pac-Man, in which PacMan players and Ghosts are equipped with Nokia phones that have an RFID tag embedded in the shell of the phone. Both Pac-Man and Ghost Players move around a physical space to collect pills (discs with RFID tags). However, ghosts can also collect pills which give them points and allow them to know the last position of the Pac-Man players. If the Pac-Man player collects a "power pill," then the Pac-Man player can kill ghosts, which forces them to return to the central location of the maze.
Articles: https://ieeexplore-ieee-org.prox.lib.ncsu.edu/document/1598509 (O. Rashid, P. Coulton, R. Edwards and W. Bamford, "Utilising RFID for mixed reality mobile games," 2006 Digest of Technical Papers International Conference on Consumer Electronics, Las Vegas, NV, 2006, pp. 459-460, doi: 10.1109/ICCE.2006.1598509), https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/1178823.1178864 (Rashid, O., Bamford, W., Coulton, P., & Edwards, R. (2006). PAC-LAN: The human arcade. Paper presented at the 33-es. doi:10.1145/1178823.1178864)

Title: PacManhattan
Description: PacManhattan consisted of Pac Man game play within the actual streets of Manhattan—a person dressed as Pac Man (wearing yellow) tried to avoid being “eaten” by other people dressed in various primary colors and simultaneously eat the virtual dots on the streets. In a remote location, players in a control room in constant contact with street players via cell phones update the street player’s physical position on a digital map of the city. The only way for the street players to know which dots have already been eaten is by talking to his or her controller.

Title: Parallel Kingdom
Description: Parallel Kingdom uses GPS and a mobile app (on iOS and Android platforms) to allow users to create virtual domains of physical places. The object of the game is to dominate or take ownership of physical spaces. To do so, players can play individually or in teams. Gameplay involves locating resources and dueling other players to achieve ownership of a place.

Title: REXplorer
Developers: Rafael Ballagas, Steffen P. Walz, Regensburg Experience Museum
Description: REXplorer is a mobile, pervasive spell-casting game designed for tourists of Regensburg, Germany. The game creates player encounters with spirits (historical figures) that are associated with significant buildings in an urban setting. A novel mobile interaction mechanism of “casting a spell” (making a gesture by waving a mobile phone through the air) allows the player to awaken and communicate with a spirit to continue playing the game. The game is designed to inform visitors about history in a fun manner.

Title: RayGun
URL: No active website for game currently exists
Description: RayGun is a commercial product that runs on a GPS-equipped mobile phone. The players have a radar-like view on their phones’ displays. The “radar” shows the location of virtual ghosts. Players then try to shoot ghosts by moving in their direction. The faster a player moves, the more powerful the shot. The energy of a shot “annoys” ghosts, and a player can expect more ghosts after shooting one. In RayGun, each player has only limited access to the virtual game world, and the level of immersion in the game depends on the player’s imagination.

Title: SCOOT
URL: No active website for game currently exists
Description: SCOOT is an SMS treasure hunt that employs web, mobile devices and public displays as tools of play to guide groups through unique public places. Simply, players must seek out mystery objects that are hidden in a public place. Along the way they participate in activities and solve clues by seeking out facts about the sites. The game intentionally requires experience in game play as well as the ability to identify and interpret cultural information.

Title: Swordfish
URL: No active website for game currently exists
Description: Swordfish is a location-based fishing game where players use their java-enabled cellular phones to find and catch virtual fish. Swordfish uses A-GPS to find the user’s current location and that of the virtual fish. A player’s general movement in his or her local area will bring the player into the vicinity of the fish, and the player can then move to a particular location to try and catch the fish. The positions are all relative, in that they do not have to be in a particular city or area to play the game.

Extending cyberspace: Location based games using cellular phones. Title: The Journey
Description: The Journey is a game developed for phones using the Symbian platform. Gameplay involves the player taking on the role of detective and navigating through a(ny) city to interact with characters to uncover the game's mystery. The game's narrative is fixed, and the player's actions do not shape the outcome of the game. However, the character must move and return to places they have visited before in order for the narrative to progress. The player's location is tracked and store in the game, which is how the game recognizes that the player has returned to a previous location. Nevertheless, there is no pre-determined significance attached to places, thus allowing the game to be played anywhere, in any city.
Articles: http://www.freeware-symbian.com/nokia-3650-device-50/adventure-games-tag/the-journey-for-symbian-download-17288.html (The Journey for Symbian, FSymbian (2010)), http://journey.andreasjakl.com/paper/p01_contents.php (The Journey - The Paper)

Title: The Journey II
URL: No active website for game currently exists
Description: The Journey II is an attempt to introduce more narrative into an adventure game. Players solve mysteries by progressing through the story and going to actual physical locations as indicated by the story. Instead of changing the gameplay on the basis of the player’s location, the game builds a virtual game environment as soon as it realizes that the player has moved. For example, at the start of the game the player’s real home can be the office, and when asked to go to another location, such as a park, the player has to move in the real world. As soon as the game detects a change in Cell ID, it prompts the player that he or she has reached the new location (the park), which in reality could be any location in the physical world. This in turn creates a virtual world as the story unfolds and the player moves back and forth through the game world until the mystery is solved.
Articles: https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/1111293.1111302 (Rashid, O., Mullins, I., Coulton, P., & Edwards, R. (2006). Extending cyberspace: Location based games using cellular phones. Computers in Entertainment (CIE), 4(1), 4-es. doi:10.1145/1111293.1111302)

Title: Tracking Agama
Description: Tracking Agama is played with a cell phone, a blog, text messages, and a voice mail system, using downtown Los Angeles as the game board. Players’ ultimate goal is to find the fictitious character Agama by exploring clues hidden in the city landscape. The online blog is the starting point of the game, where players can learn about Agama’s story and get the first tip on where to start the game in the city. From there, players collect clues embedded in city landmarks and call the voice mail system from their cell phones to provide information and get directions to the next location. Agama may also contact players via SMS.

Title: Uncle Roy All Around You
Developers: Blast Theory, Mixed Reality Lab (University of Nottingham)
URL: https://www.blasttheory.co.uk/projects/uncle-roy-all-around-you/ (Uncle Roy All Around You | Blast Theory)
Description: Multiplayer, hybrid-reality game in which remote online players use a virtual map to support a physical world player in navigating a city. The purpose of the game is for the physical world player to find a character, Uncle Roy, in under sixty minutes. The game does not make use of location services. Rather, online players guess at the location of the players in the city by seeing what part of a city map that the physical world player is looking at on their PDA.

Title: Undercover and Undercover 2
URL: No active website for game currently exists
Description: UnderCover and its sequel UnderCover 2: Merc Wars are designed to be MMORPGs based on Cell ID. Although the technology is similar to that of Botfighters, the developers have introduced greater social interaction in the second version by allowing players to enhance their experience by visiting real cities in over 44 countries by completing missions, looking for friends, enemies, and landmarks in real streets. The developers of the game are also trying to encourage commercial partnerships, ranging from: sponsored shelters or hide-outs where players are safe from enemies to product-placement advertising like branded bonus packs.  The game was available only to Java-enabled phones.

Title: Virtua Maze
URL: no website for the game, only for the device: https://buy.garmin.com/en-US/US/p/220#specs (Geko 201)
Description: A Garmin Geko 201 game, which requires a player to navigate a virtual maze to locate flags. The game keeps time for how long it takes the player to complete the maze; thus, users may race the clock to see how quickly they complete the maze.
